Package com.foreach.across.modules.spring.security.infrastructure.services

Class CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxyImpl

java.lang.Object
com.foreach.across.modules.spring.security.infrastructure.services.CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxyImpl
All Implemented Interfaces:
SecurityPrincipal, SecurityPrincipalHierarchy, CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxy
@Service public class CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxyImpl extends Object implements CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxy, SecurityPrincipalHierarchy
Provides a proxy for the Authentication, where a request is only assumed to be authenticated if the the principal associated with it is in fact a valid SecurityPrincipal.

The proxy will attempt to load the SecurityPrincipal if it is not yet available (for example only the principal name is loaded on the Authentication object). Be aware that this will done every time if the implementing Authentication does not hold the SecurityPrincipal instance.

Author:
Arne Vandamme
See Also:

    • hasAuthority

      public boolean hasAuthority(String authority)
      Description copied from interface: CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxy
      Checks if the authenticated principal has the matching authority. This does a String based comparison on GrantedAuthority.getAuthority(), whereas CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxy.hasAuthority(GrantedAuthority) will perform an equality check on the actual GrantedAuthority instance.

      String based authority checks are usually safest to use.

      Specified by:
      hasAuthority in interface CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxy
      Parameters:
      authority - string the authentication should have
      Returns:
      true if authority string was present

    • hasAuthority

      public boolean hasAuthority(org.springframework.security.core.GrantedAuthority authority)
      Description copied from interface: CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxy
      Checks if the authenticated principal has the matching exact authority. This does an equality check on the GrantedAuthority instance, meaning the type will be taken into account. In most cases using authority strings is enough, see CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxy.hasAuthority(String).
      Specified by:
      hasAuthority in interface CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxy
      Parameters:
      authority - instance the authentication should have
      Returns:
      true if authority instance was present

    • getPrincipal

      public <V extends SecurityPrincipal> V getPrincipal(Class<V> principalType)
      Description copied from interface: CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxy
      Return the SecurityPrincipal instance that is being proxied if and only if it is of the required type. In case there is a principal that does not match the type, null will be returned.
      Specified by:
      getPrincipal in interface CurrentSecurityPrincipalProxy
      Type Parameters:
      V - type of the principal
      Parameters:
      principalType - expected type of the principal
      Returns:
      instance of available and of the required type, null otherwise

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Description copied from interface: SecurityPrincipal
      Any SecurityPrincipal should return the principal name as toString() implementation to ensure maximum compatibility with SpringSecurity. Usually this is the same to calling toString() of the SecurityPrincipal.getSecurityPrincipalId().
      Specified by:
      toString in interface SecurityPrincipal
